A permanent electric quadrupole moment transforms like a rank‑2 irreducible tensor. For a particle of spin \(S\)

\[
Q_{ij}\propto\langle S,S_{z}|\,3J_{i}J_{j}-\mathbf J^{2}\delta_{ij}\,|S,S_{z}\rangle .
\]

Only spins \(S\ge 1\) possess non‑vanishing matrix elements of such a tensor. The proton has spin‑\(1/2\); therefore the above combination identically vanishes. Moreover, for a point‑like Dirac particle parity invariance forbids an intrinsic electric quadrupole moment. Hence a proton cannot carry a static electric quadrupole moment.

The time–reversal operation **T** is represented in quantum mechanics by an **anti‑unitary**
operator.  By definition it satisfies  

\[
T\, i\, T^{-1}= -i ,
\qquad 
T^{\dagger }T = TT^{\dagger}= {\bf 1}.
\]

For a particle without internal degrees of freedom one may take simply  

\[
(T\psi)(\mathbf r ,t)=\psi ^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t),
\tag{1}
\]

while for a spin‑½ particle an extra unitary rotation,
\(U=i\sigma _y\), has to accompany the complex conjugation :

\[
(T\psi)_\alpha (\mathbf r ,t)
      =\bigl(i\sigma _y\bigr)_{\alpha\beta }\;
        \psi_\beta ^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t).
\tag{2}
\]

To see why Eq.(1) follows from the Schrödinger equation, start from  

\[
i\hbar\partial_t\psi(\mathbf r ,t)=\widehat H\;\psi(\mathbf r ,t) .
\tag{3}
\]

Apply \(T\) to both sides and make use of its anti‑linearity:

\[
-i\hbar\partial_t[T\psi](\mathbf r ,t)=
    T\widehat HT^{-1}\,[T\psi](\mathbf r ,t).
\tag{4}
\]

If the dynamics is invariant under time reversal, the transformed Hamiltonian equals the original one,

\[
T\widehat HT^{-1}= \widehat H .
\tag{5}
\]

Replacing \(t\rightarrow -t\) in (4) finally gives  

\[
i\hbar\partial_{(-t)}\psi^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t)=
     \widehat H\,\psi^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t) .
\]

Hence the **time‑reversed state** obeys exactly the same Schrödinger equation,
and its wave‑function is  

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle \psi_T(\mathbf r ,t)=\psi^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t)}
\quad\text{(spinless)},
\]
or more generally  

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle (T\psi)_\alpha (\mathbf r ,t)=
          (i\sigma _y)_{\alpha\beta }
           \psi_\beta ^{*}(\mathbf r ,-t)}\qquad\text{(spin‑½)} .
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (b) Hamiltonian of a free electron with magnetic moment \(\boldsymbol\mu\) in a static field \(H_z\)

In the electron’s own rest frame there is **no kinetic energy**, so the only contribution comes from the coupling of its intrinsic magnetic dipole moment to the applied magnetic induction \({\bf B}=H_z\hat{\bf z}\):

\[
\widehat H=-\boldsymbol\mu\!\cdot\!{\bf B}.
\tag{6}
\]

For an electron   

\[
\boldsymbol\mu =-\frac{g e}{2m}\,\mathbf S
               \equiv -\gamma\,\mathbf S,
\qquad   
\gamma=\frac{g e}{2m}>0,
\]

with \(\mathbf S=(\hbar/2)\boldsymbol\sigma\) the spin operator.
Insert (7) into (6) :

\[
\widehat H=
       \gamma\,\mathbf S\!\cdot\!(H_z\hat{\bf z})
     =\gamma H_z S_z
     =\frac{\hbar\gamma}{2}\,H_z\,\sigma_z .
\tag{8}
\]

Writing the Larmor angular frequency \(\omega_L\equiv\gamma H_z\),

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\widehat H =\frac{\hbar\omega_L}{2}\,\sigma_z
            =-\boldsymbol\mu\!\cdot\!H_z\hat{\bf z}}
\]

which is the familiar Zeeman Hamiltonian for a stationary electron.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c) Operator for the time derivative of \(\boldsymbol\mu\) when a second field \(H_y\) is added  

With the extra homogeneous field pointing along the \(y\)-axis the total magnetic field becomes  

\[
\mathbf B = H_y\hat{\bf y}+H_z\hat{\bf z}.
\]

The Hamiltonian now reads  

\[
\widehat H = -\boldsymbol\mu\!\cdot\!\mathbf B
           = \gamma\,(S_y H_y+S_z H_z)
           =\frac{\hbar\gamma}{2}(H_y\sigma_y+H_z\sigma_z).
\tag{9}
\]

In the Heisenberg picture the exact operator equation of motion is  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}\boldsymbol\mu}{{\rm d} t}
   =\frac{i}{\hbar}\Big[\widehat H,\boldsymbol\mu\Big].
\tag{10}
\]

Because \(\boldsymbol\mu = -\gamma\mathbf S\) and the spin components satisfy  

\[
[S_i,S_j]=i\hbar\varepsilon_{ijk}S_k,
\tag{11}
\]

the commutator evaluates straightforwardly:

\[
\begin{aligned}
\frac{{\rm d}\mu_i}{{\rm d}t}
&=\frac{i}{\hbar}\,\gamma\,
   \big[\,S_j B_j\,,\;- \gamma S_i\big]\\[2mm]
&= -\gamma^{2}\,\varepsilon_{ijk}B_j S_k\\[2mm]
&= \gamma\;\varepsilon_{ijk}B_j\mu_k .
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the magnetic‐moment operator precesses according to the quantum analogue of the classical torque law:

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\frac{{\rm d}\boldsymbol\mu}{{\rm d}t}
      =\gamma\,\big(\boldsymbol\mu\times\mathbf B\big)} .
\tag{12}
\]

Explicitly, using \(\mathbf B =(0,H_y,H_z)\),

\[
\begin{cases}
\dfrac{{\rm d}\mu_x}{{\rm d}t}= \gamma\left(\mu_y H_z-\mu_z H_y\right),\\[4pt]
\dfrac{{\rm d}\mu_y}{{\rm d}t}= -\gamma\,\mu_x H_z, \\[4pt]
\dfrac{{\rm d}\mu_z}{{\rm d}t}= \phantom{-}\gamma\,\mu_x H_y .
\end{cases}
\tag{13}
\]

Equivalently, writing everything in terms of Pauli matrices (\(\boldsymbol\mu =-(\hbar\gamma/2)\boldsymbol\sigma\)),

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\frac{{\rm d}\boldsymbol\mu}{{\rm d}t}
   =\frac{\hbar\gamma^{2}}{2}\,
      \big(H_y\sigma_z-H_z\sigma_y\big)\,\hat{\bf x}
   +\dots } 
\]

(the compact cross‑product form (12) already contains all components.)

assistantfinalThe trial \(1s\)–wave of a hydrogen‑like atom  

\[

\qquad 
\int |\psi _a|^{2}\,d^{3}r =1,
\]

contains one variational parameter – the “Bohr” length \(a>0\).
With the Hamiltonian  

\[
H=\frac{{\bf p}^{2}}{2m}-\frac{g^{2}}{r^{3/2}},

the expectation values are

---

### Kinetic part  

\[
\langle T\rangle=
\Big\langle\psi_a\Big|\frac{-\hbar ^2\nabla ^2}{2m}\Big|
\psi_a\Big\rangle
      =\frac{\hbar ^2}{2m a^{2}}
      \equiv A\,a^{-2},
\qquad  
A:=\frac{\hbar ^2}{2m}.
\]

(The calculation uses \(\nabla ^2(e^{-r/a})=a^{-2}e^{-r/a}
-\tfrac{2}{ar}e^{-r/a}\) and integrates over all space.)

---

### Potential part  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle V\rangle &=
-g^{2}\!\int |\psi_a(r)|^{2}\,r^{-3/2}\,d^{3}r\\[2mm]
&=-g^{2}\frac{4\pi}{\pi a^{3}}
        \int_{0}^{\infty}e^{-2r/a}\,r^{1/2}\,dr \\[2mm]
&=-\frac{4g^{2}}{a^{3}}
    \frac{\Gamma(3/2)}{(2/a)^{3/2}}
     =-g^{2}\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}}\;a^{-3/2}\\[2mm]
&=: -B\,a^{-3/2},
\qquad   
B:=g^{2}\sqrt{\frac{\pi}{2}} .
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### Energy functional  

\[
E(a)=\langle H\rangle=A\,a^{-2}-B\,a^{-3/2}.
\]

Minimising with respect to \(a\),

\[
\frac{dE}{da}= -2Aa^{-3}+\frac{3}{2}Ba^{-5/2}=0
\Longrightarrow 
a^{-1/2}= \frac{3B}{4A},
\quad
a_{\!opt}= \left(\frac{4A}{3B}\right)^{2}.
\]

Insert \(a_{\!opt}\) :

\[
\boxed{
E_{\min}= -\frac{27}{256}\,\frac{B^{4}}{A^{3}}
       = -\frac{27}{128}\;
          \frac{\pi^{2} m^{3} g^{8}}{\hbar^{6}} } .
\]

In terms of the optimum scale,

\[
a_{\!opt}= \left[\frac{2\hbar^{2}}{3\,g^{2}\sqrt{\pi/2}\,m}\right]^{2}.
\]

Thus the variational estimate yields  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
E_{0}^{\;( {\rm var})}=-
\frac{27}{128}\;\frac{\pi^{2} m^{3} g^{8}}{\hbar^{6}} }
\]

as an upper bound to the exact ground‑state energy.

assistantfinal**(a)   Time development**

In the flavour basis  

\[
|\nu _e\rangle ,\qquad |\nu _\mu\rangle ,\qquad |\nu _\tau\rangle ,
\]

the un‑perturbed Hamiltonian is \(H_{0}=M_{0}\mathbf 1\).
The perturbation is taken to have the constant matrix element  
\( \langle\alpha|V|\beta\rangle=\hbar\omega _1\;( \alpha\neq\beta)\)   
and vanishing diagonal entries,

\[
V=
\hbar\omega _1 
\begin{pmatrix}
0&1&1\\[2pt]
1&0&1\\[2pt]
1&1&0
\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Hence the complete Hamiltonian is   

\[
H=M_{0}{\bf 1}+V .
\]

Only the part \(V\) produces transitions, therefore we work in the
interaction picture and drop the trivial overall phase
\(\exp[-\,{\rm i}M_{0}t/\hbar]\).

---

### Eigen–states of \(V\)

The matrix \(K\equiv V/(\hbar\omega _1)\) has eigen‑values  

\[
\lambda_{1}=2,\qquad \lambda_{2}=\lambda_{3}=-1,
\]

with normalised eigenvectors  

\[
\begin{aligned}
|+\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt 3}
            \big(|\nu _e\rangle+|\nu _\mu\rangle+|\nu _\tau\rangle\big),
\\[2mm]
|a\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt 2}
           \big(|\nu _e\rangle-|\nu _\mu\rangle\big), \\[2mm]
|b\rangle &=\frac{1}{\sqrt 6}
          \big(|\nu _e\rangle+|\nu _\mu\rangle-2|\nu _\tau\rangle\big).
\end{aligned}
\]

Their associated energies (relative to the common mass \(M_{0}\)) are  

\[
E_{+}=2\hbar\omega _1,\qquad    
E_{a}=E_{b}=-\hbar\omega _1 .
\]

---

### Expansion of the initially prepared state  

At \(t=0\) a pure \(\nu _e\) is produced :

\[
|\psi (0)\rangle =|\nu _e\rangle =
\frac{1}{\sqrt 3}|+\rangle+
\frac{1}{\sqrt 2}|a\rangle+
\frac{1}{\sqrt 6}|b\rangle .
\]

Its time evolution (again omitting the universal phase
\({\rm e}^{-\mathrm{i}M_{0}t/\hbar}\)) reads  

\[
|\psi (t)\rangle=
\frac{{\rm e}^{-{\rm i}2\omega _1 t}}{\sqrt 3}|+\rangle
+\frac{{\rm e}^{+{\rm i}\omega _1 t}}{\sqrt 2}|a\rangle
+\frac{{\rm e}^{+{\rm i}\omega _1 t}}{\sqrt 6}|b\rangle .
\]

Projecting onto the flavour states gives the amplitudes  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal A_{\nu _e}(t)&=
\frac13\Big(e^{-{\rm i}2\omega _1 t}+2e^{+{\rm i}\omega _1 t}\Big),\\[4pt]
\mathcal A_{\nu _\mu}(t)
      &=\mathcal A_{\nu _\tau}(t)
        =\frac13\Big(e^{-{\rm i}2\omega _1 t}-e^{+{\rm i}\omega _1 t}\Big).
\end{aligned}}
\]

Therefore the **probabilities** are  

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
P_{\nu _\mu}(t)=P_{\nu _\tau}(t)
     &=\left|\mathcal A_{\nu _\mu}(t)\right|^{2}
       =\frac49\sin ^2\!\Big(\frac{3\omega _1 t}{2}\Big),\\[4pt]
P_{\nu _e}(t)&=1-2P_{\nu _\mu}(t)
             =1-\frac89\sin ^2\!\Big(\frac{3\omega _1 t}{2}\Big).
\end{aligned}}
\]

These expressions satisfy \(P_{\nu _e}+P_{\nu _\mu}+P_{\nu _\tau}=1\) at any
time.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b)   Detectability of the oscillations**

The detector looks for a change of at least \(1\%\) in the composition,
so we require  

\[
P_{\nu _\mu}(t_{\rm fl})\ge 0.01 .
\tag{1}
\]

For the experimental set‑up  

* flight length \(L=2000\ {\rm m}\);
* neutrino energy \(E=100\ {\rm GeV}\);
* neutrino rest mass \(M_{0}=20\ {\rm eV}/c^{2}\),

the transit time is essentially the light‑travel time  

\[
t_{\rm fl}\simeq\frac{L}{c}= \frac{2000}{3\times10^{8}}\;
               {\rm s}=6.7\times10^{-6}\ {\rm s}.
\]

When the argument of the sine in the exact probability (above) is
small (\(3\omega _1 t_{\rm fl}\ll 1\)), Eq.(1) reduces to the quadratic
approximation  

\[
P_{\nu _\mu}\;\approx\;\frac49\Big(\frac{3\omega _1 t_{\rm fl}}{2}\Big)^{2}
                =(\omega _1 t_{\rm fl})^{2}.
\]

Consequently the smallest angular frequency that can be resolved is  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\omega _{1,\min } \;=\; \frac{\sqrt{0.01}}{t_{\rm fl}}
                     \;=\; \frac{0.1}{6.7\times10^{-6}\ {\rm s}}
                     \;\approx\;1.5\times10^{4}\ {\rm s^{-1}} } .
\]

Multiplying by Planck's constant gives the minimum detectable energy
splitting caused by the perturbation:

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\hbar\omega _{1,\min }\;=\;\hbar\,\omega _{1,\min }
                         \;\approx\;1.05\times10^{-34}\times1.5\times10^{4}
                         \;{\rm J}

The rf field \(\mathbf h(t)\) must contain components **perpendicular** to the static field \(\mathbf H_0\).

\[

\langle m'|\mu_{x,y}|m\rangle\neq 0,\qquad
\langle m'|\mu_{z}|m\rangle =0\;(m'\ne m).

\[

\]

\[

    =\frac{\gamma}{2\pi}\,\mu_0 H_0 .
\]

      =\frac{\gamma}{2\pi}\,\mu_0 H_0 \times 10^{-6}

When the rf field is turned on, the induced transitions tend to drive the

* **Spin‑lattice (longitudinal) relaxation**, characterised by time \(T_1\), restores the Boltzmann imbalance set by the static field.
* **Spin‑spin (transverse) relaxation**, characterised by \(T_2\), destroys phase coherence among the excited spins.

Two kinds of contributions appear :

* **Paramagnetic (Van‑Vleck)** – mixing with nearby states having non‑zero

\[

     \simeq \mu_{B},\qquad

\]

For an electron (\(q=-e\)) placed in a static uniform electric field \( {\bf F}=F\,\hat x\),

\[
U_{\text{field}}(x)= -qFx = (+e)\,F x .
\]

The full one‑dimensional Hamiltonian therefore reads  

\[
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2m}+ \underbrace{\frac12 kx^{2}}_{V_{\rm ho}(x)}
      + eF x .
\]

Define the natural frequency of the unperturbed harmonic oscillator  

\[
\omega=\sqrt{k/m},\qquad 
x_{0}\equiv\frac{eF}{k}.
\]

---

### (a) Shift of the energy levels

Complete the square in the potential:

\[
\begin{aligned}
V(x)&=\tfrac12 kx^{2}+eFx\\[2pt]
    &=\frac{k}{2}\Big[x^{2}+2\frac{eF}{k}x\Big]\\[2pt]
    &=\frac{k}{2}\big[(x+x_{0})^{2}-x_{0}^{2}\big].
\end{aligned}
\]

Consequently,

\[
H=\frac{p^{2}}{2m}+ \frac{k}{2}(x+x_{0})^{2}
   -\frac{k}{2}x_{0}^{2}.
\]

Introduce the shifted coordinate  
\(y=x+x_{0}\); then the Hamiltonian becomes that of a *standard* harmonic
oscillator plus a constant:

\[
H=\left[\frac{p_y^{2}}{2m}+ \frac12 m\omega^{2}y^{2}\right]-\frac{k}{2}x_{0}^{2},
\qquad p_y=p .
\]

Its eigenenergies are therefore

\[
E_{n}= \hbar\omega\!\left(n+\tfrac12\right)-\frac{k}{2}x_{0}^{2},
\qquad n=0,1,2,\dots
\]

Since the original (unperturbed) levels were   
\(E_{n}^{(0)}=\hbar\omega\,(n+\tfrac12 )\), the **energy shift**
caused by the electric field is the constant term

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
\Delta E_{n}=E_{n}-E_{n}^{(0)}=
-\frac{k}{2}\,x_{0}^{2}
=-\frac{e^{2}F^{2}}{2k}}\;,
\]

which is independent of the quantum number \(n\).
(The first–order Stark effect vanishes because \(\langle n|x|n\rangle=0\);
the non‑zero shift appears already at second order.)

---

### (b) Dipole moment in state \(n\)

The dipole moment associated with state \(|n\rangle\) is defined as  

\[
P_{n}= -e\;\langle n | x | n\rangle .
\]

In the shifted coordinates \(y=x+x_{0}\) the eigenstates are those of a centred
harmonic oscillator, for which \(\langle y\rangle_{n}=0\). Hence

\[
\langle x\rangle_{n}= \langle y-x_{0}\rangle_{n}= -x_{0}
                 = -\frac{eF}{k}.
\]

Plugging into the definition,

\[
P_{n}= -e\big(-\frac{eF}{k}\big)
     = \frac{e^{2}F}{k}.
\]

Again the result does not depend on \(n\):

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
P_{n}= \frac{e^{2}F}{k}}
\qquad (n=0,1,2,\ldots ).
\]

--- 

Thus the uniform external electric field lowers all harmonic‑oscillator
levels by the amount \(-e^{2}F^{2}/(2k)\) and induces a permanent dipole
moment \(e^{2}F/k\) pointing opposite to the applied field.

Below we describe each experiment, point out the features that cannot be explained classically, and show how a quantum picture resolves them.

---

## 1.   Photo‑electric Effect  *(quantisation of radiation)*  

### Experimental arrangement  
A clean metallic surface is illuminated by monochromatic light of frequency \( \nu\). An external retarding potential \(V\) is applied between the metal and a collector electrode so that only electrons whose kinetic energy exceeds \(e|V|\) reach the detector. By varying either the incident wavelength or the intensity of the beam one measures the **photo‑current** \(I(V,\nu)\).

### Classical expectation  
In Maxwell’s wave theory the electric field amplitude scales with the square root of the light intensity. A stronger beam should therefore deliver more energy to the conduction electrons, giving:
* a larger electron emission rate,
* no threshold frequency – even very low‑frequency waves would eventually liberate electrons given enough time,
* a kinetic‐energy distribution independent of the illumination frequency (only proportional to intensity).

### Observations (non‑classical)
1. **Existence of a cut‑off frequency:** No electrons are emitted unless \(\nu > \nu_{0}\) (material dependent). Increasing the intensity below this frequency does not help.
2. **Linear dependence on frequency:** For \(\nu>\nu_0\) the maximum kinetic energy obeys  
   \[
   K_{\max}=h\nu-\phi ,
   \tag{1}
   \]
   where \(\phi\) is the work function of the metal. Changing the intensity changes only the current magnitude, never \(K_{\max}\).
3. **Instantaneous emission:** Electrons appear essentially without delay after the light is switched on, contrary to the idea of gradual heating required by a classical wave.

### Quantum interpretation  
Einstein (1905) postulated that light consists of *quanta* (later called photons) carrying indivisible packets of energy
\[
E_\text{photon}=h\nu .
\tag{2}
\] 
When a single photon strikes an electron it may transfer its whole energy. Energy conservation gives Eq.(1): part of the photon energy (\(h\nu\)) overcomes the binding energy \(\phi\); the remainder appears as the electron’s kinetic energy. Because a photon has fixed energy, there is a sharp threshold when \(h\nu<\phi\). The number of emitted electrons is proportional to the photon flux, i.e. to the light intensity, explaining the observed increase of photocurrent while leaving \(K_{\max}\) unchanged.

Thus the photo‑electric effect demonstrated **quantisation of the electromagnetic field**—light behaves as particles (“photons”) with energy \(h\nu\).

---

## 2.   Franck–Hertz Experiment  *(quantisation of bound‑electron states / mechanical system)*  

### Experimental arrangement  
Electrons are thermionically emitted from a heated cathode, accelerated through a variable voltage \(U_a\) toward a grid placed before a collecting plate. Inside the tube lies a dilute vapor of mercury (or another noble gas). As the accelerating voltage increases, the collected current \(I(U_a)\) is recorded.

### Classical expectation  
If electrons interact continuously with the atoms via Coulomb forces, their kinetic energy would decrease smoothly with distance due to many small collisions. One would expect a monotonic rise of the current with increasing acceleration because higher‑energy electrons overcome any modest retardation.

### Observations (non‑classical)

1. **Series of distinct minima** in the current occurring at regular intervals of the accelerating voltage (≈ 4.9 V for Hg). After each minimum the current rises again until the next drop.
2. **Emission of characteristic line radiation** coincident with the voltages at which the current drops sharply (observed spectroscopically as the well‑known Hg resonance lines).

These facts imply that electrons lose a *fixed amount* of kinetic energy during certain collisions rather than a continuous spread.

### Quantum interpretation  

Bohr’s atom model (1913) posits that bound electrons occupy stationary energy levels \(E_n\) and can absorb/emit radiation only when making transitions between these levels, with the transition energy satisfying
\[
\Delta E = h\nu_{nm}=E_m-E_n . \tag{3}
\]

In the Franck–Hertz apparatus an incoming free electron collides elastically with a mercury atom most of the time, preserving its kinetic energy. When its kinetic energy reaches exactly the excitation energy of the first allowed electronic transition,
\[
K_e^{\rm inc}=E_2 - E_1 \approx 4.9~{\rm eV},
\tag{4}
\]
it can undergo an **inelastic collision**, transferring precisely this amount to promote the atom from ground state \((n=1)\) to the excited state \((n=2)\). Consequently the scattered electron emerges with near zero kinetic energy and fails to surmount the collection grid, producing a dip in the measured current. 

After the excited atom relaxes radiatively (emitting a photon of wavelength \(\lambda\simeq254\,\mathrm{nm}\)), the atom returns to the ground state and becomes available for further excitations, leading to the periodic repetition of the phenomenon at multiples of 4.9 V.

Equation (4) shows that the **kinetic energy of a macroscopic particle (the projectile electron)** is exchanged in integer multiples of a fundamental quantum \(\Delta E=h\nu\). This provides direct evidence that **matter itself possesses discrete internal energy spectra**, confirming Bohr’s hypothesis and establishing the concept of quantised bound‑state energies for mechanical systems.

---

## Summary of What Was Learned  

| Experiment | Quantity shown to be quantised |
|------------|--------------------------------|
| **Photo‑electric effect** | Energy of individual **radiation quanta**: \(E_{\gamma}=h\nu\). |
| **Franck–Hertz**          | Internal **energies of bound electrons** in atoms: \(\Delta E = h\nu_{nm}\). |

Both experiments revealed that nature does **not** allow arbitrary division of energy exchange; instead, exchanges occur in integral multiples of Planck’s constant times a frequency. This dual insight laid the foundation for modern quantum mechanics, unifying the treatment of fields (photons) and material systems (atoms, molecules, solids).

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Radiation : }E_{\text{photon}}=h\nu ,\\[4pt]
&\text{Atomic levels : }\Delta E_{mn}=E_m-E_n = h\nu_{mn}.
\end{aligned}}
\]

      =\frac{p^{2}}{2M}+ \tfrac12 (2k)\,x^{2},
\qquad 
\omega _2=\sqrt{2k/M}= \sqrt{2}\;\omega _1 .
\]

For a given frequency \(\omega\) the ground–state wave function is  

\[

                     \exp\!\biggl[-\frac{M\omega}{2\hbar }x^{2}\biggr].
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a)   Probability to stay in the ground state after the quench  

Immediately after the spring constant is doubled the state of the particle is **still**
the ground state of \(H_{1}\).  
The probability to find it in the new ground state \(|0\rangle_{\!2}\) is therefore the
overlap square

\[
P_{00}=|\langle 0_{\!2}\mid 0_{\!1}\rangle|^{2}.
\]

With \(\alpha_i\equiv M\omega_i/\hbar\;(i=1,2)\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle 0_{\!2}\mid 0_{\!1}\rangle
&=
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\!
dx\,
\left(\frac{\alpha_2}{\pi}\right)^{1/4}
\left(\frac{\alpha_1}{\pi}\right)^{1/4}
e^{-(\alpha_1+\alpha_2)x^{2}/2}\\[2mm]
&=
\Bigl(\frac{2\sqrt{\alpha_1\alpha_2}}
            {\alpha_1+\alpha_2}\Bigr)^{1/2}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Consequently  

\[
P_{00}= \frac{2\sqrt{\alpha_1\alpha_2}}{\alpha_1+\alpha_2}
       =\frac{2\sqrt{\omega_1\omega_2}}{\omega_1+\omega_2}.
\]

Since \(\displaystyle\frac{\omega_2}{\omega_1}= \sqrt{2}\),

\[
\boxed{
P_{00}= \frac{2\sqrt{\sqrt{2}}}{1+\sqrt{2}}

\sum_{n}c_n\,e^{-iE_n^{(2)}T/\hbar}\,|n\rangle_{\!2},

assistantfinal**Ground‑state “quantum‑bouncer’’**

The Hamiltonian for a point–mass moving only vertically above a perfectly rigid floor is  

\[
\hat H=\frac{-\hbar ^2}{2m}\,\frac{{\rm d}^{2}}{{\rm d}z^{2}}+mg\,z ,\qquad 
z>0 ,
\]
with the boundary condition \(\psi (0)=0\).  
Only the three quantities \(m\;( {\rm mass}),\;g\;( {\rm acceleration})\) and
Planck’s constant \(h\) may appear in the ground‑state energy,
so we write the most general dimensional combination as  

\[
\boxed{\;\varepsilon =K\,m g\Bigl(\frac{m^{2}g}{h^{2}}\Bigr)^{\!\alpha }\;}
\tag{1}
\]

and determine the exponent \(\alpha\) by dimensional analysis.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (a) Determination of \(\alpha\)

Dimensions :

\[
[m]={\sf M},\quad[g]={\sf LT^{-2}},\quad[h]={\sf ML^{2}T^{-1}},
\qquad[\varepsilon]={\sf ML^{2}T^{-2}} .
\]

Inside the parenthesis,

\[
\biggl[\frac{m^{2}g}{h^{2}}\biggr]
   =\frac{{\sf M^{2}}({\sf LT^{-2}})}{{\sf M^{2}L^{4}T^{-2}}}
   ={\sf L^{-3}} .
\]

Raising to the power \(\alpha\) gives \({\sf L^{-3\alpha }}\).   
Multiplying by the prefactor \(m g\,(={\sf ML T^{-2}})\) we obtain  

\[
[\varepsilon]\sim {\sf M L^{1-3\alpha }T^{-2}}
               ={\sf M L^{2}T^{-2}} .
\]

Equating the exponents of \(L\):

\[
1-3\alpha =2\Longrightarrow \boxed{\alpha =-\dfrac13 } .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### (b) Variational estimate of the constant \(K\)

A convenient trial function obeying \(\psi(0)=0\) is  

\[
\psi_{\beta }(z)=N\,z\,e^{-\beta z},
\qquad \beta>0 ,
\]
with normalisation  

\[
N^{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}z^{2}e^{-2\beta z}{\rm d}z=1
      \;\Rightarrow\;
N=2\sqrt{\beta ^3}.
\]

---

#### Expectation values

*Kinetic energy*

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle T\rangle &=
-\frac{\hbar ^2}{2m}\int_{0}^{\infty}\!
\psi_\beta (z)\,\psi_\beta ''(z){\rm d}z\\[2mm]
&=\frac{\hbar ^2\beta ^2}{2m}.
\end{aligned}
\]

*Gravitational potential*

\[
\begin{aligned}
\langle V\rangle &= mg\int_{0}^{\infty}\!
\psi_\beta ^2(z)\,z\,{\rm d}z \\[2mm]
&= \frac{3\,mg}{2\beta } .
\end{aligned}
\]

Consequently  

\[
E(\beta)=\frac{\hbar ^2\beta ^2}{2m}+\frac{3mg}{2\beta } .
\]

---

#### Minimisation

Setting \(\displaystyle\frac{{\rm d}E}{{\rm d}\beta}=0\) gives  

\[
\frac{\hbar ^2\beta }{m}-\frac{3mg}{2\beta ^2}=0
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\beta _0^{\,3}= \frac{3m^{2}g}{2\hbar ^2}.
\]

Inserting \(\beta _0\) back into \(E(\beta)\) yields the minimum (the
variational approximation to the true ground‑state energy)

\[
\boxed{
E_{\min}=C\,\hbar ^{2/3}m^{1/3}g^{2/3}},\qquad 
C\simeq1.97 .
\]

Writing the result in the form (1) requires expressing everything through
the ordinary Planck constant \(h=2\pi\hbar\):

\[
E_{\min}=C\Bigl(\frac{\hbar}{h}\Bigr)^{2/3}
          \;m g\Bigl(\frac{m^{2}g}{h^{2}}\Bigr)^{-1/3}
        \equiv K\,m g\Bigl(\frac{m^{2}g}{h^{2}}\Bigr)^{-1/3},
\]

so that  

\[
\boxed{K=C\,(2\pi)^{-2/3}\approx0.58 } .
\]

(The exact quantum‑mechanical result is
\(E_{0}=|a_{1}|( \hbar ^2 g^{2}m/2)^{1/3}\) with \(|a_{1}|=2.338…\);
its corresponding \(K\) equals \(0.54\), showing that the variational
estimate is quite satisfactory.)

### Numerical evaluation for \(m=1\;{\rm g}\)

Using CGS units:
\[
m=1\;{\rm g},\qquad g=980\;{\rm cm\,s^{-2}},\qquad 
h=6.626\times10^{-27}\;{\rm erg\,s},
\]
and the obtained constant \(K\simeq0.58\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\varepsilon &=
K\,m g\Bigl(\frac{m^{2}g}{h^{2}}\Bigr)^{-1/3}\\[2mm]
            &\approx0.58\times(1)(980)
              \times\Bigl(\frac{1^{2}\cdot980}{(6.626\times10^{-27})^{2}}\Bigr)^{-1/3}\\[2mm]
            &\approx2.0\times10^{-16}\;{\rm erg}
             \; (=2\times10^{-23}\;{\rm J}) .
\end{aligned}
\]

\boxed{\varepsilon(m=1\;{\rm g})\;\approx\;2\times10^{-16}\ {\rm erg}}
\]

Q\,C|\psi _q\rangle = Q\,|\psi_{-q}\rangle =(-q)\,|\psi_{-q}\rangle .
\]

\[
Q\,C|\psi _q\rangle =-\,C\,Q|\psi _q\rangle\quad\Longrightarrow\quad  
\boxed{\;\{C,Q\}=CQ+QC=0\;}
\tag{1}
\]

i.e. **\(C\) and \(Q\) anticommute**.

\[
A = 0 .
\]

\[
\boxed{\lambda =0 } .

C|\phi\rangle = c |\phi\rangle ,

Let's craft response accordingly.assistantfinal**1. Why the “old” problem was *to stop* an atom from glowing**

Before quantum mechanics the motion of charged particles was described completely by **classical electrodynamics**.  
An electron moving on a closed orbit around a positively‑charged centre is constantly accelerated, therefore according to the Larmor formula  

\[
P_{\text {rad}}=\frac{e^{2}\,a^{2}}{6\pi\varepsilon_{0}c^{3}},
\qquad 
a=\frac{v^{2}}{r},
\]

it must lose energy as electromagnetic radiation.   
If one inserts typical atomic numbers (\(v\simeq \alpha c,\ r\simeq a_0\)) one obtains a radiated power \(P\sim10^{-8}{\rm W}\); the corresponding orbital‐decay time is

\[
\tau\;\approx\;\frac{\tfrac12 m_ev^{2}}{P}
      \;\sim\;10^{-11}\ {\rm s}.
\]

Hence a purely classical hydrogen atom would collapse onto its nucleus within a few picoseconds – clearly contrary to the existence of long–lived matter.   

The **theoretical crisis** was thus:

> *“How could an electron revolve forever without radiating?”*

Bohr’s ad‑hoc postulate (“stationary orbits”) solved this phenomenologically: certain privileged orbits were declared non‑radiative, while jumps between them emitted quanta of light. But the deeper question — why an accelerating charge sometimes does **not** radiate — remained unanswered until quantum theory supplied a new description of both matter and the electromagnetic field.

---

**2. Why the “new” problem was *to make* an excited atom glow**

Quantum mechanics provides **discrete, normalizable eigenstates** \(|n\rangle\) of the atomic Hamiltonian \(H_A\) with energies \(E_n\). An isolated atom prepared in an excited eigenstate \(|e\rangle\) has a perfectly well‑defined energy and, under the *Schrödinger* evolution generated solely by \(H_A\),

\[
|\psi(t)\rangle=e^{-iE_e t/\hbar}|e\rangle ,
\]

does **never** change its internal state—it would stay excited forever. Yet experiments show that such atoms inevitably return to lower‑energy states, emitting photons.  

Consequently, once the atom itself was understood, the next theoretical task became:

> *“What physical ingredient forces a quantum‑mechanically stable excited level to decay and release a photon?”*

The answer lies in recognizing that the atom cannot be truly isolated: it is always coupled to the **quantum electromagnetic field**, whose degrees of freedom constitute an infinite set of harmonic oscillators (the various photon modes).

---

**3. Mechanism of spontaneous emission**

The total Hamiltonian reads

\[
H=H_A+H_F+\underbrace{H_{\!int}}_{-\mathbf d\!\cdot\!\mathbf E(\mathbf r)},
\qquad 
\mathbf d = q\,\mathbf r,
\]

where \(H_F\) describes the free photon field and the interaction term couples the atomic electric dipole \(\mathbf d\) to the local electric‑field operator \(\mathbf E\). Even when there are **no real photons** present, the field possesses **vacuum fluctuations**:
\[
\langle 0 | \mathbf E(\mathbf r,t)\,\mathbf E(\mathbf r',t')|0\rangle\neq 0 .
\]

Treating \(H_{\!int}\) as a small perturbation and applying time‑dependent perturbation theory (Fermi’s Golden Rule) gives the transition rate from \(|e\rangle\) to a lower state \(|g\rangle\) plus a photon of wavevector \(\mathbf k\) and polarization \(\lambda\):

\[
\Gamma_{e\rightarrow g}= \frac{2\pi}{\hbar}
   |\langle g,1_{\mathbf{k},\lambda}|H_{\!int}|e,0\rangle|^{2}
   \rho(\omega),
\]
with the density of photonic states \(\rho(\omega)=\frac{\omega^{2}V}{\pi^{2}c^{3}}\).
Evaluating the matrix element yields the familiar **Einstein‑A coefficient** (or Weisskopf–Wigner result)

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle 
\Gamma_{e\rightarrow g}
    =\frac{\omega_{eg}^{3}}{3\pi\varepsilon_{0}\hbar c^{3}}
       \,|\mathbf d_{ge}|^{2}},\qquad 
\omega_{eg}=(E_e-E_g)/\hbar .
\]

Key points:

* The **continuum of field modes** supplies a channel through which the atom can shed excess energy.  
* The **zero‑point (vacuum) fluctuations** act like a stochastic driving force that perturbs the atomic dipole, initiating the transition even though no external photon is present.  
* Once a photon is created, the process becomes indistinguishable from **stimulated emission**; indeed, the same interaction Hamiltonian governs both phenomena—the difference being whether the stimulating mode already contains photons.

Therefore, *spontaneous emission* is nothing mysterious: it is simply the unavoidable consequence of a quantum system interacting with another quantum system (the electromagnetic vacuum) that possesses infinitely many accessible states.

---

### Final statement

- **Pre‑QM:** Classical electromagnetism demanded continuous radiation from any orbiting electron → the paradox was to *prevent* this radiation.  
- **Post‑QM:** Quantised atomic energy levels remove the classical paradox, but now the puzzle reverses: why do *excited* quantised states *inevitably* lose energy?  

**Answer:** An excited atom emits light because its electric dipole is permanently coupled to the quantised electromagnetic field. Vacuum fluctuations of that field supply the necessary perturbation, allowing the atom to transfer its excitation energy into a photon occupying one of the endless field modes—a process quantitatively described by the Einstein‑\(A\) (spontaneous‑emission) coefficient derived from quantum electrodynamics.  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\text{Excited atoms emit because of their irreversible coupling to the vacuum modes of the quantised EM field (spontaneous emission).}}
\]

assistantfinal**Solution**

The potential  

\[
V(x)=\begin{cases}
0,&|x|>a\\[2pt]
-\,V_{0},&|x|\le a ,
\end{cases}\qquad   V_{0}>0
\]

is a **square‑well** of width \(2a\).
A particle of mass \(m\) has a positive total energy \(E\;(>0)\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1. Wave functions and matching conditions  

Outside the well (\(|x|>a\))

\[
k=\sqrt{\frac{2mE}{\hbar ^2}},\qquad   
\psi_{\rm out}(x)=Ae^{ikx}+Be^{-ikx}\quad (x<-a),\qquad    
\psi_{\rm out}(x)=Fe^{ikx}\quad (x>a),
\]

where \(A\) represents the incident beam coming from the left,
\(B\) the reflected amplitude and \(F\) the transmitted amplitude.

Inside the well (\(|x|\le a\))

\[
q=\sqrt{\frac{2m\,(E+V_{0})}{\hbar ^2}},\qquad  
\psi_{\rm in}(x)=Ce^{iqx}+De^{-iqx}.
\]

Continuity of \(\psi\) and \(\psi'\) at \(x=\pm a\) gives four linear equations;
solving them eliminates the intermediate coefficients \(C,D\) and relates
the outgoing amplitudes \(B,F\) to the incoming amplitude \(A\).

It is convenient to use the **transfer‑matrix** formalism.  
Writing the state vector \((\psi,\psi')^{\!T}\) on both sides of the well,

\[
\begin{pmatrix}\psi \\ \psi' \end{pmatrix}_{x=a}
=
M\,
\begin{pmatrix}\psi \\ \psi' \end{pmatrix}_{x=-a},
\qquad     
M=
\underbrace{
\begin{pmatrix}
\cos qa & \dfrac{1}{q}\sin qa\\[4pt]
-q\sin qa & \cos qa
\end{pmatrix}}_{\displaystyle M_{\rm free}}
\!
\underbrace{
\begin{pmatrix}
\cos ka & \dfrac{1}{k}\sin ka\\[4pt]
-k\sin ka & \cos ka
\end{pmatrix}}_{\displaystyle M_{\rm free}^{-1}},
\]

which after straightforward multiplication yields the element needed for
transmission:

\[
M_{11}= \cos (q\,2a)-i\;\frac{k^{2}+q^{2}}{2kq}\,\sin (q\,2a).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2. Transmission and reflection probabilities  

From the definition of the transmission amplitude  

\[
t=\frac{F}{A}= \frac{1}{M_{11}}\;,
\]

we obtain  

\[
\boxed{%
T\equiv|t|^{2}= 
\frac{1}{
\cos ^{2}(q\,2a)
+
\Bigl[\frac{k^{2}+q^{2}}{2kq}\Bigr]^{2}
\sin ^{2}(q\,2a)}
 } .
\tag{1}
\]

Using unitarity of the scattering matrix (or directly evaluating the
reflection amplitude) one finds  

\[
\boxed{%
R\equiv|r|^{2}=1-T }
\tag{2}
\]

so that indeed \(R+T=1\) for all energies.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3. Condition for perfect transmission  

Equation (1) shows that the only way to have \(T=1\) is to make the second
term under the denominator vanish, i.e.

\[
\sin (q\,2a)=0\Longrightarrow q\,2a=n\pi ,\qquad n=0,1,2,\dots
\]

Since \(n=0\) corresponds to the trivial case of infinite wavelength,
the **first genuine resonance** occurs for  

\[
\boxed{ q=\frac{n\pi}{2a}\,,\qquad n=1,2,\ldots }      \tag{3}
\]

At these discrete energies the phase accumulated while travelling across
the attractive well is exactly an integral multiple of \(\pi\);
the two partial waves emerging from the front and rear faces interfere
constructively in the forward direction and destructively backward,
producing **zero reflection**.  
This is the quantum‐mechanical explanation of the **Ramsauer–Townsend
effect**: even though the electron feels an attractive potential,
its wavelike nature allows it to “fit” into the atomic size and pass
through without being scattered.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4. Numerical estimate for Helium  

Experimentally the first transparency window for He appears at  

\[
E_{\min}=0.7~\mathrm{eV}.
\]

Taking the atomic radius as the half‑width of the well,
\(a=0.10\ {\rm nm}=1.0\times10^{-10}\,{\rm m}\), the resonance condition
(3) with \(n=1\) reads  

\[
q=\frac{\pi}{2a}= \frac{\pi}{2\times10^{-10}\,{\rm m}}
               =1.5708\times10^{10}\ {\rm m^{-1}} .
\]

Because \(q^{2}=2m(E+V_{0})/\hbar^{2}\),

\[
E+V_{0}= \frac{\hbar^{2}q^{2}}{2m}
        =\frac{(1.0545718\times10^{-34}\,{\rm J\,s})^{2}
                (1.5708\times10^{10}\,{\rm m^{-1}})^{2}}
              {2(9.1093836\times10^{-31}\,{\rm kg})}
        =1.50\times10^{-18}\ {\rm J}
        =9.38\ {\rm eV}.
\]

Consequently  

\[
\boxed{ V_{0}= (E+V_{0})-E\simeq 9.38\ {\rm eV}-0.70\ {\rm eV}
       \approx 8.7\ {\rm eV}. }
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
## Final Answers  

*Transmission and reflection probabilities*

\[
\boxed{%
T=\frac{1}{
\cos ^{2}(2aq)+\bigg[\dfrac{k^{2}+q^{2}}{2kq}\bigg]^{2}
\sin ^{2}(2aq)},\qquad       
R=1-T } .
\]

*Resonant (perfect‑transmission) condition*

\[
\boxed{ q\,2a=n\pi\;(n=1,2,\dots ) }\qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad
\boxed{ T=1 } .
\]

*Depth of the square‑well modelling a He atom*

\[
\boxed{ V_{0}\;\approx\;8.7\ \text{eV}. }
\]

These results reproduce quantitatively the Ramsauer–Townsend minima
observed experimentally for low‑energy electron scattering off noble‑gas atoms. 

\[
\boxed{ V_{0}\simeq 8.7\ \text{eV} }
\]

\[

assistantfinal**(a) Central–field approximation**

In a many‑electron atom the exact non‑relativistic Hamiltonian  

\[
H=\sum_{i}\Big[-\,\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2m_e}\nabla _i^{2}
-\frac{Ze^{2}}{r_i}\Big]
+\sum_{i<j}\frac{e^{2}}{|\mathbf r_i-\mathbf r_j|}
\]

contains the complicated pairwise Coulomb repulsions \(e^{2}/|\mathbf r_i-\mathbf r_j|\).
The **central‑field (or mean‑field) approximation** replaces the true
potential felt by any electron by a *spherically symmetric* “average’’ potential  
\(V_{\rm cf}(r)\),

\[
H\simeq\sum_{i}\bigg[-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2m_e}\nabla_i^{2}+V_{\rm cf}(r_i)\bigg],
\qquad 
V_{\rm cf}(r)=-
\frac{Z_{\rm eff}(r)e^{2}}{r},
\]

where \(Z_{\rm eff}(r)\) includes the screening produced by the other
electrons.  Because \(V_{\rm cf}(r)\) depends only on the distance \(r\),
the one‑electron operator commutes with the orbital‐angular‑momentum
operators \(\hat {\bf L}^{2}\) and \(\hat L_z\).  Consequently its eigenfunctions
can be chosen simultaneously as eigenfunctions of  

\[
\hat H,\;\hat {\bf L}^{2},\;\hat L_z,\;
\hat {\bf S}^{2},\;\hat S_z .
\]

Hence a *single‑electron* stationary state may be labelled uniquely by  

* **principal quantum number   \(n\)** – fixes the radial node structure and
approximately the binding energy;

* **orbital‑angular‑momentum quantum number   \(\ell\)** –
\(|\mathbf L|=\sqrt{\ell (\ell+1)}\,\hbar\);

* **magnetic quantum number   \(m_\ell\)** – the component of \(\mathbf L\)
along a chosen quantisation axis, \(m_\ell=-\ell,-\ell+1,\dots,+\ell\);

* **spin projection   \(m_s\)** – eigenvalue of \(\hat S_z\);
for an electron \(s=1/2\) so \(m_s=\pm\tfrac12\).

These four numbers therefore specify completely the orbital shape,
its orientation in space, and the intrinsic magnetic moment due to spin.



--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(b) Periodic‑table pattern and the role of \(\ell\)**  

Below is a schematic picture of the first four periods. Each small square
represents one chemical element; the colour / shading indicates the block
to which it belongs (s‑block, p‑block, …). Only the layout matters – the
elements themselves need not be named.

```
Period 1 :    □  □                         (2 elements)

Period 2 :    □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □         (8 elements)

Period 3 :    □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □         (8 elements)

Period 4 :    □  □      □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □  □
               ↑s     ↑p                ↑d                 ↑f*
(*only up to d shown for the fourth period*)
```

*Explanation via QM*

1. **Aufbau (building‑up) principle** – electrons occupy the available
one‑electron levels in order of increasing energy.   
   Within the central‑field picture the energies depend primarily on the
quantity \(n+\ell\) (“Madelung rule”) and, for equal \(n+\ell\), on the smaller
\(n\). This ordering reproduces exactly the sequence of blocks seen above:
\(1s\;(n=1,\ell=0)\rightarrow 2s\,(2,0)\rightarrow 2p\,(2,1)\rightarrow
3s\,(3,0)\rightarrow 3p\,(3,1)\rightarrow 4s\,(4,0)\rightarrow 3d\,(3,2)\rightarrow
4p\,(4,1)\ldots\)

2. **Why low \(\ell\) fills first for a given \(n\)?**  
   For fixed principal quantum number \(n\) the centrifugal barrier
\(\propto \ell(\ell+1)/r^{2}\) pushes the electronic probability density outward.
Electrons with larger \(\ell\) experience stronger shielding by inner
electrons and feel a weaker net nuclear attraction, raising their energy.
Consequently the hierarchy \(\ell=0(s)<\ell=1(p)<\ell=2(d)<\ell=3(f)\) holds,
giving rise to the characteristic “blocks” of the periodic table.


--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(c) LS (Russell–Saunders) coupling**

When spin–orbit interaction is weak compared with electrostatic interactions
(the case for light atoms), individual orbital angular momenta \({\boldsymbol\ell}_i\)
and spins \({\bf s}_i\) couple *separately* :

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf L &=\sum_i \boldsymbol\ell_i &&\text{total orbital }L\\[2pt]
\mathbf S &=\sum_i {\bf s}_i          &&\text{total spin }S\\[2pt]
\mathbf J &=\mathbf L+\mathbf S       &&\text{total angular momentum }
\end{aligned}}
\]

A complete atomic level is denoted by the **term symbol**

\[
^{2S+1}L_J ,
\]

with  

* multiplicity \(2S+1\) (singlet, doublet, triplet,…),  
* \(L\) written as a letter: \(L=0\!\to\!S,\;1\!\to\!P,\;2\!\to\!D,\;3\!\to\!F,\dots\)  
* subscript \(J\) taking the values \(|L-S|,|L-S|+1,\dots ,L+S\).

p^{2}= -\frac{\hbar m\omega}{2}\bigl[(a-a^{\dagger})^{2}\bigr].
\]

Since \((a+a^{\dagger})^{2}=a^{2}+a^{\dagger 2}+aa^{\dagger}+a^{\dagger}a\) and similarly for the momentum term, and recalling that in a coherent state all normally ordered products factorise,

\[
\langle a^{\dagger}a\rangle =|\alpha|^{2},\qquad
\langle aa\rangle =\alpha^{2},
\qquad
\langle a^{\dagger}a^{\dagger}\rangle =(\alpha^{*})^{2},
\]

\[

\begin{aligned}
\langle x^{2}\rangle &=
\frac{\hbar}{2m\omega}\Bigl(1+2|\alpha|^{2}+ \alpha^{2}+(\alpha^{*})^{2}\Bigr),\\[4pt]
\langle p^{2}\rangle &=
\frac{\hbar m\omega}{2}\Bigl(1+2|\alpha|^{2}- \alpha^{2}-(\alpha^{*})^{2}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}}
\]


--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (c) Position and momentum uncertainties  

From the results above

\[
\Delta x^{2}= \langle x^{2}\rangle-\langle x\rangle^{2}
             =\frac{\hbar}{2m\omega},
\qquad
\Delta p^{2}= \langle p^{2}\rangle-\langle p\rangle^{2}
             =\frac{\hbar m\omega}{2}.
\]

Therefore  

\[
\sigma _x\equiv\Delta x=\sqrt{\frac{\hbar}{2m\omega}},\qquad
\sigma _p\equiv\Delta p=\sqrt{\frac{\hbar m\omega}{2}} .
\]

Their product is  

\[
\sigma_x\sigma_p=\frac{\hbar}{2},
\]

exactly the lower bound of the Robertson–Heisenberg inequality. Hence **coherent states saturate the uncertainty principle**, just as the ground state does.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (d) Expansion in the number basis  

Write  

\[
|\alpha\rangle=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n|n\rangle ,\qquad 
a|n\rangle=\sqrt{n}\,|n-1\rangle .
\]

Acting with \(a\) on the series and using the defining eigenvalue equation,

\[
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n\sqrt{n}\,|n-1\rangle
   =\alpha\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_n|n\rangle .
\]

Shift the index on the left-hand side (\(k=n-1\)) :

\[
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_{k+1}\sqrt{k+1}\,|k\rangle
   =\alpha\sum_{k=0}^{\infty}c_k|k\rangle .
\]

Equality of the coefficients of each \(|k\rangle\) gives the recursion  

\[
c_{k+1}= \frac{\alpha}{\sqrt{k+1}}\,c_k .
\]

Iterating,

\[
\boxed{c_n=\frac{\alpha^{\,n}}{\sqrt{n!}}\,c_0 } .
\]

Normalization requires  

\[
1=\langle\alpha|\alpha\rangle
   =|c_0|^{2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{|\alpha|^{2n}}{n!}
   =|c_0|^{2}e^{|\alpha|^{2}},
\]

so that  

\[
\boxed{c_0=e^{-|\alpha|^{2}/2}} ,
\]

choosing the overall phase to be unity. Consequently  

\[
|\alpha\rangle=e^{-|\alpha|^{2}/2}
              \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{\alpha^{n}}{\sqrt{n!}}|n\rangle .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### (e) Time evolution  

The Schrödinger picture evolution is  

\[
|\alpha(t)\rangle = e^{-iHt/\hbar}\,|\alpha\rangle .
\]

Because \(H=\hbar\omega\bigl(a^{\dagger}a+\tfrac12\bigr)\),

\[
a(t)\equiv e^{iHt/\hbar}\,a\,e^{-iHt/\hbar}
        =ae^{-i\omega t},
\qquad
a^{\dagger}(t)=a^{\dagger}e^{+i\omega t}.
\]

\[
a\,|\alpha(t)\rangle
   =e^{-iHt/\hbar}\,a(t)\,|\alpha\rangle
   =e^{-iHt/\hbar}\,e^{-i\omega t}a|\alpha\rangle
   =e^{-i\omega t}\alpha\,|\alpha(t)\rangle .
\]

Thus \(|\alpha(t)\rangle\) remains an eigenstate of the **annihilation operator** with a **time‑dependent eigenvalue**

\[
\boxed{a(t)=\alpha\,e^{-i\omega t}} .
\]

\[

e^{-|\alpha|^{2}/2}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}
\frac{\bigl(\alpha e^{-i\omega t}\bigr)^{n}}{\sqrt{n!}}\,e^{-i\omega nt}\,|n\rangle,
\]

showing again that the label \(\alpha\) simply rotates in the complex plane.

### (f)  The ground state as a coherent state  

Take \(\alpha=0\). From (d),

\[
|0\rangle = e^{-0}\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{0^{n}}{\sqrt{n!}}|n\rangle
           =|0\rangle .
\]

Moreover \(a|0\rangle =0\); hence the ground state obeys the definition of a coherent state with eigenvalue  

\[
\boxed{\alpha=0}.
\]

So the vacuum is indeed a special (trivial) coherent state.

scattering is completely **isotropic**, i.e. independent of the polar angle
\(\theta\). Up to an overall numerical factor the result is what was asked for:
the “multiplicative constant’’ is \(m^{2}a^{2}/(4\pi^{2}\hbar^{4})\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------

## Why the same behaviour appears for any short‑range potential at low momentum

Consider now a general central potential \(V(r)\) whose support extends only over a
finite radius \(R\) (“short‑range”). Its first‑order Born amplitude is

\[
f(\theta)=-
\frac{m}{2\pi\hbar^{2}}
\underbrace{\int d^{3}r\,
               e^{-i\mathbf q\!\cdot\!{\bf r}}V(r)}_
            { \displaystyle \tilde V(\mathbf q)},
\qquad 
\mathbf q\equiv\mathbf k'-\mathbf k ,\quad
q=2k\sin\frac{\theta}{2}.                                   \tag{5}
\]

Expand the exponential for **small transferred momentum**
\(qR\ll 1\):

\[
\tilde V(\mathbf q)=\int d^{3}r\,V(r)
                    \left[1-i\mathbf q\!\cdot\!{\bf r}
                          -\tfrac12(\mathbf q\!\cdot\!{\bf r})^{2}+ \dots\right].
\]

Because the integrand is spherically symmetric, all odd powers vanish after
angular integration, leaving

\[
\tilde V(\mathbf q)=\underbrace{\int d^{3}r\,V(r)}_{=:A}
                     \Bigl[1-\mathcal O\!(q^{2}R^{2})\Bigr] .
\tag{6}
\]

Thus, provided

\[
\boxed{ \;kR\;\ll\;1\;} \qquad\Longleftrightarrow\qquad
pR/\hbar\ll 1,
\tag{7}
\]

the dominant contribution to the amplitude is just the **zero‑momentum
Fourier component** \(A\). Substituting (6) into (5) one obtains

\[
f(\theta)\simeq -
\frac{mA}{2\pi\hbar^{2}}\,[1+\mathcal O(k^{2}R^{2})],
\]

which again is independent of direction. Consequently the **differential
cross‑section** takes the universal low‑energy form

\[
\boxed{
\frac{{\rm d}\sigma}{{\rm d}\Omega}
\simeq \frac{m^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\hbar^{4}}\,A^{2}
\qquad(pR\ll\hbar).
}
\tag{8}
\]

Only the overall constant changes—from \(a\) for the pure delta potential to
the space integral \(A=\int d^{3}r\,V(r)\) for any other short‑range force—while
the **energy (no explicit \(p\) dependence) and angular independence** remain
identical. Higher‑order terms in the expansion generate corrections of relative
size \(\sim (pR)^{2}\), producing weak angular structure once the condition
(7) ceases to hold.

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### Final compact result

For the specific contact interaction \(V(\mathbf r)=a\delta^{3}(\mathbf r)\)

\[
\boxed{
\frac{{\rm d}\sigma}{{\rm d}\Omega}
   =\frac{m^{2}a^{2}}{4\pi^{2}\hbar^{4}}\;,
}
\]

and for any finite‑range potential satisfying \(pR\ll\hbar\) the same functional
form holds with the replacement \(a\rightarrow\displaystyle\int d^{3}r\,
V(r)\). This demonstrates the universality of the low‑momentum (long‑wavelength)
behaviour of scattering off short‑range forces.

\[
\boxed{\;\psi(\mathbf r,t+2t_{1})=\psi(\mathbf r,t)\;}
\]

\[
\boxed{T=2t_{1}}
\tag{10}
\]

### 4. Quantisation of the spectrum  

Equation (9) together with the definition (10) reads

\[

\qquad m_n\in\mathbb Z .
\tag{11}
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\Delta E = \frac{2\pi\hbar}{T}},
\]

\[
\boxed{E_n = n\frac{2\pi\hbar}{T}},\qquad n\in\mathbb Z .

If a system evolves under a real Hamiltonian and its wavefunction happens
to be real at two different instants, it necessarily repeats itself
periodically. The period is twice the separation between the two real
instants,

\[
\boxed{T = 2t_{1}} .
\]

All stationary‐state energies are constrained to be integral multiples of
the frequency associated with that period,

\[
\boxed{E_n = n\frac{2\pi\hbar}{T}},\qquad n\in\mathbb Z .
\] 

These statements follow directly from expanding the state in a real
eigenbasis of the Hamiltonian and imposing the reality conditions at the
two specified times.

No other real turning points exist, therefore the motion consists of three distinct zones  

* **Zone I:**   \(x<x_{1}\) (classically allowed – travelling waves);  
* **Zone II:**  \(x_{1}<x<x_{2}\) (classically forbidden – exponentially growing/decaying solutions);  
* **Zone III:**\(x>x_{2}\) (classically allowed – outgoing wave).

The stationary Schrödinger equation (\(\hbar =1\)) reads  

\[
-\frac{d^{2}\psi}{dx^{2}}+V(x)\,\psi =E\,\psi ,
\qquad 
k(x)=\sqrt{E-V(x)},\;\;
\kappa(x)=\sqrt{V(x)-E}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Local WKB solutions

In the allowed regions (I & III)  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\psi_{\rm al}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{k(x)}}\Big[A\,e^{+i\int^{x}k(s)\,ds}
      +B\,e^{-i\int^{x}k(s)\,ds}\Big] }
\tag{1}
\]

and in the forbidden region (II)  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\psi_{\rm fo}(x)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\kappa(x)}}
     \Big[C\,e^{+\int^{x}\kappa(s)\,ds}
          +D\,e^{-\int^{x}\kappa(s)\,ds}\Big]} .
\tag{2}
\]

Close to either turning point the WKB approximation fails; however the **Airy‑function connection formulas** give the precise relationship between the constants that appear just to the left and just to the right of a simple turning point.

Let us denote by \((A,B)\) the pair of coefficients immediately **to the left**
of a turning point and by \((C,D)\) those immediately **to the right**.   
For a *downward* crossing (allowed→forbidden) the standard Stokes‐phenomenology
gives  

\[
\begin{pmatrix}C\\ D\end{pmatrix}=M_{\uparrow}
        \begin{pmatrix}A \\ B\end{pmatrix},
\qquad    
M_{\uparrow}= 
\begin{pmatrix}
\dfrac12&0\\[6pt]
0&\dfrac{i}{2}
\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{3a}
\]

Conversely, for an *upward* crossing (forbidden→allowed),

\[
\begin{pmatrix}F\\ G\end{pmatrix}=M_{\downarrow}
       \begin{pmatrix}C \\ D\end{pmatrix},
\qquad     
M_{\downarrow}= 
\begin{pmatrix}
1&i\\[6pt]
-i&1
\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{3b}
\]

These matrices embody the well‑known rules  

\[
e^{+i\int k\,dx}\;\longrightarrow\;\tfrac12\,e^{+\int\kappa\,dx},
\qquad
e^{-i\int k\,dx}\;\longrightarrow\;\tfrac{i}{2}\,e^{-\int\kappa\,dx},
\tag{4}
\]

and their inverses obtained by analytic continuation around the Stokes lines.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Propagation through the forbidden slab  

Inside zone II the two independent exponentials simply acquire the factor
generated by integrating \(\kappa(x)\) over the distance between the turning
points:

\[
\begin{aligned}
C' &= C\,e^{\displaystyle\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\!\kappa(s)\,ds},
\\[4pt]
D' &= D\,e^{-\displaystyle\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\!\kappa(s)\,ds}.
\end{aligned}
\tag{5}
\]

Define the **action integral**

\[
\Gamma\equiv\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\kappa(s)\,ds>0 .
\tag{6}
\]

Equation (5) can thus be written compactly as  

\[
\begin{pmatrix}C'\\ D'\end{pmatrix}=P(\Gamma)
    \begin{pmatrix}C\\ D\end{pmatrix},
\qquad       
P(\Gamma)=
\begin{pmatrix}
e^{\Gamma}&0\\[4pt]
0&e^{-\Gamma}
\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{7}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Global transfer matrix  

Collecting all steps—first crossing at \(x_{1}\), propagation through the gap,
second crossing at \(x_{2}\)—the total transformation from the incident/
reflected amplitudes \((A,B)\) in region I to the transmitted/amplitudes
\((F,G)\) in region III is

\[
\begin{pmatrix}F\\G\end{pmatrix}
=
M_{\downarrow}\, P(\Gamma)\, M_{\uparrow}
\begin{pmatrix}A\\B\end{pmatrix}
\equiv {\cal T}(\Gamma)
\begin{pmatrix}A\\B\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{8}
\]

Carrying out the matrix multiplication,

\[
{\cal T}(\Gamma)=
\begin{pmatrix}
1+i\,e^{-2\Gamma} &\; i\,(1-e^{-2\Gamma})\\[6pt]
-i\,(1-e^{-2\Gamma}) &\; 1-i\,e^{-2\Gamma}
\end{pmatrix}.
\tag{9}
\]

If only a beam coming from the left impinges on the barrier we set
\(B=r\,A\) (reflection amplitude) and demand that there be **no incoming wave**
from the right, i.e. \(G=0\). Solving the lower row of Eq.(8) under this condition
produces the familiar expressions

\[
r=\frac{-i\,\sinh\Gamma}{\cosh\Gamma}= -i\tanh\Gamma ,
\qquad
t=\frac{e^{-\Gamma}}{\cosh\Gamma}= \operatorname{sech}\Gamma .
\tag{10}
\]

Here \(t\) multiplies the forward‑going plane wave in region III,
so the **probability transmission coefficient** is

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
T\equiv|t|^{2}= \operatorname{sech}^{2}\!\Gamma
           =\frac{1}{\cosh ^{2}\!\Gamma}}
\tag{11}
\]

while the **reflection coefficient** follows from unitarity,

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
R\equiv|r|^{2}= \tanh^{2}\!\Gamma

\tag{12}
\]

\[
\boxed{
\displaystyle
T\simeq e^{-2\Gamma}
      =\exp\!\Bigl[-2\!\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\!

\quad (\Gamma\gg 1).
\tag{13}
\]

### 5.  Physical interpretation  

* The action \(\Gamma\) measures how much “imaginary momentum’’ the particle has
inside the sloped part of the barrier.  
* Equation (13) shows that the dominant suppression of the transmitted flux is
exponential in exactly the same way as for a rectangular barrier; the slope
only enters through the shape of \(\kappa(x)\) inside the integral.  
* The pre‑exponential factor \(\operatorname{sech}^{2}\Gamma\) accounts for the
interference of the two partial reflections generated at the two turning
points. When the barrier width happens to satisfy  

\[
\Gamma=n\pi\;(n\in\mathbb Z),
\]

the denominator \(\cosh\Gamma\) reaches its minimum and resonant enhancement
(``over‑the‑top'' resonance) occurs, producing peaks in the transmission even
though the particle’s energy lies below the top of the barrier.

**downward** turning point at \(x_{2}\) (with no further classical turning
points) the scattering amplitudes are completely determined by the single
integral  

\[
\Gamma=\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\!\sqrt{V(x)-E}\;dx .
\]

The corresponding probabilities are  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
T = \operatorname{sech}^{2}\!\Gamma
   =\frac{1}{\cosh^{2}\!\Gamma}},\qquad
\boxed{\displaystyle
R = \tanh^{2}\!\Gamma = 1-T } .
\]

In the limit of a thick/high barrier these reduce to the usual WKB tunnel-
penetration law  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle
T \;\underset{\Gamma\gg1}{\simeq}\;
\exp\!\Bigl[-2\!\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}}\!
               \sqrt{V(x)-E}\;dx\Bigr] } .
\] 

These formulas constitute the required analysis based on the proper WKB
connection formulas for the two sloping turning points.

**(b)   Excited‑state variational theorem**

The Rayleigh–Ritz (variational) principle furnishes an upper bound not only
to the ground‐state energy but also to any excited level provided the
trial function belongs to the subspace that is **orthogonal to all lower
exact eigenstates**.  Explicitly, if \(|\chi\rangle\) satisfies  

\[
\langle \psi_{0}|\chi\rangle =
\langle \psi_{1}|\chi\rangle =\cdots=
\langle \psi_{n-1}|\chi\rangle =0 ,
\]

then  

\[
\frac{\langle\chi|\hat H|\chi\rangle}{\langle\chi|\chi\rangle}
\ge E_{n},
\]

so the minimized expectation value gives an upper bound to the
\(n^{\text{th}}\) eigenvalue.

---

### Application to the one‑dimensional harmonic oscillator

For the harmonic oscillator  

\[
\hat H=\frac{-\hbar ^2}{2m}\frac{{\rm d}^{2}}{{\rm d}x^{2}}
+\frac12 m\omega ^2 x^{2},
\]

the exact eigenfunctions possess definite parity:
the ground state \(\psi_{0}(x)\) is even, while the first excited state
\(\psi_{1}(x)\) is odd.

A simple even trial function that reproduces well the ground state is  

\[

\begin{cases}
a^{2}-x^{2}, & |x|<a,\\[2mm]
0,           & |x|\ge a .
\end{cases}
\]

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\phi_{1}(x)=x\,\phi_{0}(x)},
\]

which is **odd**, hence automatically orthogonal to any even function,
including the exact ground state \(\psi_{0}\) and the even trial
\(\phi_{0}\):
\[
\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\phi_{1}(x)\,\phi_{0}(x){\rm d}x=0 .
\]

Moreover \(\phi_{1}\) possesses exactly one node at the origin – the
characteristic feature of the genuine first excited harmonic‑oscillator
state (\(\propto x\,e^{-m\omega x^{2}/2\hbar }\)).  Therefore \(\phi_{1}\)
lies in the admissible subspace for the first excited level, and the
Rayleigh–Ritz procedure performed with \(\phi_{1}\) delivers an upper
bound to \(E_{1}=\tfrac32\hbar\omega\).

\[

\[

Thus, for truly low incident momenta the **partial‑wave result reduces to the simple geometric form**
\[
\sigma_{\text{PW}}=4\pi\Bigl[a-\frac{\tan(\gamma a)}{\gamma}\Bigr]^2,
\]
while the **Born approximation**, being only accurate to second order in the interaction strength, gives a cross section proportional to \(V_{0}^{2}a^{6}\) and misses the possible resonant increase associated with a shallow bound state of the well.

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{\text{exact}} &=
4\pi\Biggl[a-\frac{\tan\!\bigl(a\sqrt{2mV_{0}/\hbar^{2}}\bigr)}
               {\sqrt{2mV_{0}/\hbar^{2}}}\Biggr]^{2},
\\[4pt]
\sigma_{\text{Born}} &\simeq
\frac{256\pi^{3}m^{2}V_{0}^{2}a^{6}}{\hbar^{4}}
\qquad (ka\ll1).
\end{aligned}
\]}
